planner.name: Plan-A 1.0
planner.author: Qiang Lv, Yixin Chen, Ruoyun Huang
planner.description: Note: This planner is not guaranteed to produce globally optimal solutions, but solutions which are optimal with respect to a certain planning horizon. It participated noncompetitively.

argument.name: output type
argument.description: (0) create CNF output or (1) build final solution

argument.name: output file
argument.description: to specify output file

argument.name: fixed number of time steps
argument.description: to specify a fixed number of time steps

argument.name: info level
argument.description: to specify tracing info level 1 or 2 (default is 0)

argument.name: plan graph length
argument.description: increment plan graph by length n

argument.name: don't graphplan solver
argument.description: don't skip graphplan solver

argument.name: stop first solution
argument.description: stop as soon as a solution found

argument.name: print literal form
argument.description: print wff in literal form

argument.name: print propositional form
argument.description: print wff in propositional (.cnf) form

argument.name: literals to propositions
argument.description: map mapping from literals to propositions

argument.name: print model
argument.description: print model returned by solver

argument.name: exit after printing wff
argument.description: exit after printing wff

argument.name: print solution in literal form
argument.description: print the solution plan in literal form, rather than lisp notation

argument.name: alternative max nodes
argument.description: to specify alternative max nodes in a time step (default is 2048)

argument.name: failure mode
argument.description: halt if solvers go into failure mode N times in a row (default 4)

argument.name: timeout N times
argument.description: halt if solvers timeout N times in a row (default 8)

argument.name: halt after plans of length N are reached
argument.description: halt after plans of length N are reached (default 50)

argument.name: minimal set of exclusiveness
argument.description: only generate minimal set of exclusiveness relationships

argument.name: aximos
argument.description: or default (7), mutex (15), compressed (31), expanded (63), action (129), dagsat (319)

argument.name: maximum global time limit
argument.description: maximum global time limit N seconds (default 1800)

argument.name: solver
argument.description: -solver SPEC { -then SPEC }* sequence of solver specifications, must be the last argument. Format of SPEC: SPEC == { -maxit N } { -maxsec F } COMMAND {solver specific options}. COMMAND == graphplan || satz || walksat || relsat || compact -maxsec F == only run solver for F seconds -maxit N == only run solver for N iterations (flips/backtracks/recursions) If maxsec or maxit are not specified, then use the most recently set value. Default values are 0 (meaning no limit). To get options for particular solvers (e.g. walksat) try blackbox -help -solver walksat

COMMAND == graphplan || satz || walksat || relsat || compact -maxsec F == only run solver for F seconds -maxit N == only run solver for N iterations (flips/backtracks/recursions) If maxsec or maxit are not specified, then use the most recently set value. planner.name: MaxPlan
planner.author: Xing Zhao, Yixin Chen, Weixiong Zhang, and Ruoyun Huang
planner.description: MaxPlan is an automated optimal propositional based on a satisfiability (SAT) formulation of STRIPS planning. The key innovation of MaxPlan is its use of the long distance mutual exclusion (londex), a novel generalization of the classic mutual exclusion (mutex). Based on a multi-valued domain formulation, londex provides much stronger space pruning than mutex since it can capture constraints relating actions not only at the same time step but also across multiple time steps. Several other novel techniques, including backward level reduction, accumulative learning of clauses, and SAT constraint partitioning, are also developed to further improve the search efficiency for both satisfiability solving and unsatisfiability proving.Winner of the 1st Prize, Optimal Planning Track, Deterministic Part of the 5th International Planning Competition (IPC5), 2006.

argument.description: Final Output Solution File Name (only when -G 1 is used)

argument.name: output type
argument.description: (0) create CNF output or (1) build final solution

argument.name: CNF formula output
argument.description: CNF formula output (preset: -1); at layer -l. 0 none, 1 action-based, 2 gp-style action-based, 3 gp-based, 4 thin gp-based

planner.name: LPRPG
planner.author: A. I. Coles, M. Fox, D. Long, and A. J. Smith
planner.description: LPRPG is a heuristic forward search planner that uses similar techniques to FF and Metric-FF. The key difference lies in its handling of numbers. The numeric effects of actions are translated into constraints in a linear program during the construction of the reachability graph. This allows LPRPG to combine the relaxation reasoning for propositional parts of the planning problem with a linear program solution of the numeric parts. The result is a more effective guide when domains involve complex metric behaviour, particularly where resources flow around the domain or are exchanged for one another.

argument.name: Use standard EHC
argument.description: Use standard EHC instead of steepest descent;

argument.name: Skip HC
argument.description: Skip HC - go straight to best-first search;

argument.name: Disable helpful-action pruning
argument.description: Disable helpful-action pruning.

planner.name: Marvin
planner.author: Andrew Coles or Amanda Smith
planner.description: Marvin is a domain-independent forward-chaining heuristic-search planner, written by Andrew Coles and Amanda Smith; it competed in the recent Fourth International Planning Competition. Marvin stands for Macro-Actions from Reduced Versions of the INstance: problems are solved by learning macro-actions through solving a smaller, automatically generated, instance and then using these in the process of solving the original, larger, problem instance. Marvin supports the following features of PDDL2.1: STRIPS; ADL; Derived Predicates. It does not yet support fluents or temporal planning. The basic search strategy used is an extension of FF's enforced hill-climbing; the extensions made include the use of memoised plateau-escaping sequences as reusable macro-actions, identification of transformational operators, cycle detection, and support for ADL and derived predicates without the need for compilation of the domain before search.

argument.name: Go straight for best-first search - skip EHC step
argument.description: Normally Marvin attempts to solve the problem using Enforced Hill-Climbing, resorting to Best-First Search if this fails. If you know that EHC will fail on your problem then pass this option to make it go straight into trying BestFS.

argument.name: Do not memoise plateau-escaping action sequences
argument.description: Disable the memoisation of plateau-escaping action sequences.

argument.name: Disable symmetric action choice pruning
argument.description: Do not prune the number of actions applicable in a given state by only considering actions applying to one exemplar in each symmetry group.

argument.name: Do not solve reduced instance prior to specified problem
argument.description: Skip the step which produces a reduced instance of the original problem and attempts to solve that first. This step is automatically skipped if the reduced problem isn't any smaller.

argument.name: Sequential (implicit if domain contains derived predicates)
argument.description: Do not attempt to plan actions concurrently.

argument.name: Do not recognise transformational operators (implies -r not being passed)
argument.description: Do not attempt to recognise simple transformation operators.

argument.name: Verbose
argument.description: Be verbose about the planning process.
